title: Grieving My Old Life

content: A lot of feelings come with being diagnosed with a chronic illness. It’s often very bittersweet. On one hand, you want answers. On another, you don’t want to have to live with something for the rest of your life. Shortly after being diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis, I started to feel an intense amount of grief.

Grief usually comes in waves. I’ll be OK with my current life for a while, but then out of nowhere, I’ll remember something I used to be able to do, or someone I used to be friends with, and the wave crashes over me.

I used to be a really active person. I would go for lots of bike rides, do yoga, and do workouts like Insanity Max 30. I loved being active. It was my outlet. If I was upset, I would just work out. I always felt better after a workout.
These days, working out fatigues me and knocks me out for days. Depending on what it is, at least. I can handle a short walk every day, or every other day. Possibly a bike ride on a really good day.

content: It’s upsetting! I miss being able to work out whenever I want and doing whatever I want. I have to keep in mind the fatigue that comes after now. If I were to do a workout video now, I don’t know what would happen to me. I think I would collapse and be out of commission for a few days.

In the days before my onset of symptoms and diagnosis, I would also go out a lot. I would work a lot! I worked at a restaurant and was on my feet all day. I think my body would fall apart if I tried one day of work at my old workplace. Standing for more than 10 minutes at a time starts to bother me and hurt my back and pelvis. It truly feels like another lifetime that this all happened in.

content: It’s been 7 years now since I got sick with AS, but the grief never really gets easier. As I said earlier, it comes in waves. I’ll be totally OK with being sick (for the most part) one moment and crying about my life the next. The crying usually comes when my symptoms start to flare. I start to miss my old life and hate my current one.

content: It’s an overwhelming feeling. I often go to a dark place when this happens. A place where I’m feeling extremely negative about myself. “I don’t want to be sick anymore,” I’ll cry. “I can’t do this anymore.” “I hate this.” These are some of the thoughts that cross my mind when I’m feeling this way.
The grief can last anywhere from a few hours to a few days, depending on how bad the symptoms are.

I know that I’m not alone in this feeling. A lot of us go through it. How can you not? My life has completely changed since I was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. I could have never imagined this for myself when I turned 21. Life has changed forever.
When I feel this intense emotion, I will often cry it out. I find it healing to have a good, hard cry about things sometimes. It’s healthy and it lets everything out.

content: I’ll also talk to a friend who has the capacity to listen to me vent or journal out my feelings. It’s not an easy emotion to feel, and often we’re used to grieving the loss of other people, not ourselves. It’s a foreign feeling. It doesn’t feel right, but it is. It’s completely valid for us to grieve the life we once had because that is our past and nothing can change that.
Dealing with grief in healthy ways is what I’ve found best when the wave crashes over me.
